titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
My Servant-man John Thomas was very sick; threatened with a pleurisy fever— I sent for Dr Woodward who bled him, and gave directions for his Regimen— Mr Withington came, and we went into the Woods for a new Survey of the Lot upon which there is a question of Title— Captain Josiah Bass— Deacon Ebenezer Adams Deacon Spear and his brother William Peter Turner, and Mr Withington’s Grand-son were with us; but the business was yet not completed— I produced my deeds and plans; but that which was taken in December 1826. when I was absent, I could not find. My Son George sent it to me at Washington, and I probably left it there— Mr Turner wished that the Lot should be measured crosswise, which was done; but before we had got near through the length of the lot, Mr Withington gave out, and said he could go no further.
They agreed however that Mr Withington should project the plan from the undisputed bound, so as to make up the quantity of Land contained in the Deed to my father.— I walked from Owen’s field home with Peter Turner, over the rocks and Hills— Found Mr Litchfield the Mason, at work in my chamber, reducing the fireplace; and Mr Mills, the Painter, painting my bookshelves.— The Lieutenant had attended the Sale of Furniture at the Railway House, and did not get back till after we had dined— Peter Turner was here after dinner, with an old deed from Samuel Bass to my Grandfather John Adams dated 1716. and which he thought would settle the question of title; but it proved to be land in the 9th. lot, while ours is in the 7th. I received a Letter from James Maury, late Consul of the United States at Liverpool enclosing one from James Barbour late Minister to Great-Britain dated 20. August— Read this Evening several Letters of Madame du Deffand— The Account of Dr. Franklin’s presentation at Court, and of Voltaire’s arrival at Paris, and Death, are interesting.
2. IV. Friday.

I changed my sleeping chamber; the painting of the Book-shelves in that which I am fitting up for my Library having given it an offensive smell— I took the upper, North-east corner chamber, and finding it very cold this Morning, made the fire in the dining room, and read there. Then worked an hour in the Garden with the Spade, finding that I could not write in the Office till after breakfast. Mr Newell came with a subscription paper for the continuation of Silliman’s Journal, to which I put my name. Mr Litchfield finished the reduction of my fire-place in my bed chamber, and made a brick back-log in the middle chamber and room— I resumed after several days of interruption the writing of the Memoir, but am yet unable to average with it a page a day. Towards Evening I walked to my brother’s, and spent an hour with his family. After returning I read several Letters of Madame du Deffand—all in the same strain— They present a melancholy picture of human wretchedness arising from blindness, solitude, old age, and sleepless Nights. The singularity of her affectionate attachment to Walpole is not more remarkable than its pertinacity. For a long series of years it continued in spite of constant harsh treatment, of which she constantly complains— The inferences most conclusively to be drawn from their collection of Letters are 1. The absolute necessity of a blind person to have some one person upon to concentrate all the affections of the heart— The absence of all affection in a blind person for any other than the special favourite— The total indifference towards all others; even to the most intimate acquaintance 3. The extreme anxiety to be well thought of even by those for whom nothing but this indifference is felt. 4. The misery of being without religious impressions. She is occasionally sensible of this, and says in one of her Letters that she knows Devotion would be her best resource if she could feel it— She seems to have had a dull unexamining, fixed and unalterable disbelief of a future State of existence; which she does not positively acknowledge; but which you distinctly perceive in all her Lamentations— Among the remarkable things in the Letters are the pains which she takes to suppress her dislike of Gibbon, and especially of his History, which she cannot endure and is yet unwilling to condemn, because it was much admired by Mr Walpole. The correspondence flags after the commencement of the War between France and Great-Britain in 1778. but I perceive with some surprize, that both she and her correspondent appear to entertain doubts whether any serious War would arise, until after the battle between the fleets of 27. July 1778.
3. V. Saturday.

A cold morning and warm day. Mr Wallace called while we were at Breakfast— He had a Patent for a Quarter Section of Soldier’s bounty Lands in the State of Illinois, issued to his brother in 1818. and left as he says by Will to him. But there are some arrears of taxes due upon it; and he came to enquire what he was to do to save the land from forfeiture. I told him if he wished to know where the Land was to write to Mr George Graham Commissioner of the General Land-Office; and he would inform him to whom and where he must pay the arrears of taxes— The Lighter Sloop Flash, Captain Bicknell, arrived from Boston with 38 boxes, and 5 Trunks of Books belonging to me; which have been packed up, partly in England whence they were sent to Boston in 1817. and the rest since they were dismissed from the Boston Athenaeum in 1822. They were all brought up in Mr Seaver’s waggon, in four loads from the wharf at the Canal, and were landed in my yard before one O’Clock P.M. Five boxes of them were brought into the Entry, and the rest placed for shelter from probable rain under the Woodshed— Josiah Adams junr. was still putting up bookshelves in my bed chamber, and Mr Mills was painting them. I called at Elisha Turner’s, to order a winter waistcoat, and visited his mother Mary, eldest daughter of my father’s brother Peter Boylston Adams— Then went to my brother’s and delivered a Letter to his daughter Abigail, received from Washington, with one from my dear wife, and one from my Son John— Mr John B. Davis and his brother William a boy ten years of age, dined with us; as did my brother and his Son the Lieutenant.— Also Miss Anna Thaxter who walked from Hingham, and remains with us over the Sunday— I had some conversation with J. B. Davis upon political subjects, and he shewed me an Essay from the pen of Dr Waterhouse— I lent him for his perusal my Manuscript reply to the Confederate Appeal— I wrote to my Son Charles and to C. M. Putnam, who is stated to have delivered at a recent anniversary celebration, at Andover a Discourse upon the character of Thomas Shepard.
4. III. IV. Sunday.

I was waked by Mr Farrar’s preparations to go in to Boston with his Milk; and upon lighting my lamp found it was only three O’Clock. I returned to bed and rose again at four. The weather continued warm but there was a heavy rain till noon. I answered my Son John’s Letter— Heard Mr Whitney this morning from Luke 14.18. “And they all with one consent began to make excuse.” It was communion day, and the Sermon was a Reproof upon those Christians who neglect joining in it. Considering successively all the topics of excuse, usually alledged by those who withhold themselves from the Church. The afternoon Discourse, was a continuation of the Commentary upon the things hard to be understood in the New Testament, and reviewed the Book of Acts— Most of his remarks were upon the Account in the second Chapter of the descent of the Holy Ghost upon the Apostles on the day of Pentecost— He appeared somewhat perplexed with the cloven tongues of which he gave no satisfactory explanation, and simply gave notice that Unitarians did not admit the personality of the Holy Ghost. From the single Condition upon which Philip baptized the Eunuch, merely the declaration of his belief that Jesus was the Son of God, Mr Whitney inferred with much plausibility that no other condition is necessary for the admission of any person to all the privileges of the Christian faith, and therefore that all Creeds were superfluous— Some very slight historical notices were given of Luke, Paul and Barnabas—but these Sermons do not fulfil the expectations which they raise— They solve no difficulties—they explain nothing— They do not even set forth the real passages hard to be understood— Those Subjects are indeed better suited to formal Dissertations than to popular Sermons. Mr Whitney did not this day name his text.
I had remarked at dinner that our Unitarian Clergymen, scarcely ever gave out for singing the hymn of Watts beginning “How beauteous are their feet”—taken from the 52d chapter of Isaiah; and said I supposed it was because it favoured the Doctrine of the Divinity of Christ— It happened that Mr Whitney gave out this afternoon that hymn, but he omitted the last two verses— I think it one of the most beautiful Odes in the language. I also read this day Dr Freeman’s Sermon 16. upon the fear of punishment and 17. upon content. This last is the best in the collection; although not with the best selected text. Mr Beale and his Son were here this Evening, and Mr W. Greenleaf— Mr Beale went with Edward Miller to New-York; but returned two days before him. It appears that Edward Miller inherits all his brother Charles’s property.
5. IV. Monday.

The Severity of the cold not only continues, so as to disqualify me for writing without a fire, but has given me a severe Catarrhal cold— Mr Noah Curtis was here this Morning; I gave him the Deed of the half-Acre of Land at the foot of Penn’s Hill for his Son; for which he paid me four hundred dollars— I told him I had not put it into the Deed as a condition but that the appraisers had fixed it that he should make the whole fence it being round his house and garden; and I understood such was the agreement between us. He said he was aware I could not at most be held to do more than maintain my part of what is called a lawful fence; perhaps of Posts and Rails; and his Son wanted something more close and permanent—but he thought as I had not agreed to the estimate of the appraisers; I did not mean to insist upon their conditions. I told him I understood the only difference between us was the price, and I had consented he should take two rods less in depth than he had proposed— He said it should make no difficulty between us. He also paid me two years interest to the 3d. for the Note of 1400 dollars to the Executors of my father, and I paid him the second and third payments in full for the Gallery Pews N. 5. 13. and 16. which my brother had purchased and upon which he had made the first payment, and has now transferred them to me; and he gave me deeds of them all. Immediately after dinner I went with the Chaise with John Thomas into Boston. Stop’d at the Stone Cutters, and found I was yet in time to change one word in the monumental Inscription, it had occurred to me yesterday, and I had great anxiety for the change. I then went immediately to Charles’s office, but he was not there—to his house where I found him with his wife suffering under a much severer cold than mine— I told him I should send in for him to-morrow Evening—left with him the 400 dollars I had received this morning to be deposited in the Bank, to-morrow, and went to Charles Brooks Hard ware shop where I purchased a pair of Andirons, Shovel, Tongs, Brush, and Bellows, with a pair of Hooks and Screws— The only remaining Article wanted was a Fender, which he had not— I brought out my things and got home about seven O’Clock— Mrs Sampson was here— Mr G. W. Beale called upon me this morning to furnish a hand, and a team of oxen to work upon the highways. I sent my newly hired man, Dutton, but had no oxen to send. This Evening I finished reading the third Volume of Madame du Deffand’s Letters, which come down to the close of the year 1779.
6. V. Tuesday.

I made the first Fire in my bed-chamber but it did not sufficiently warm the room to enable me to write, and my Diary and correspondence fell in arrear— I read the remaining Letters of Madame du Deffand to Horace Walpole including the last before her death,
and then went back to the Editorial notice of her life in the first Volume, which I read over again— She was 68 years old, and had been twelve years blind when she first became acquainted with Walpole— The correspondence extends through a period of 15 years— She died at the age of 83. Walpole was a man of rank, fortune and fashion, but of a timid character; fond of his ease, and of living in luxurious solitude at Strawberry Hill. He never was married; which for a person of his condition is conclusive evidence that all his sensibilities centered in himself— His Genius, his Elegance of taste his devotion to literary pursuits though not rare endowments to an Englishman of noble family gave him far greater dignity than the peerage that fell to him at the close of his life; but his fastidious and scolding, sometimes insulting, and yet generous friendship for Madame du Deffand, is a phenomenon; much less than hers for him; which is the strongest instance of the besoin d’aimer, that perhaps has ever occurred— What it was in Horace Walpole that fascinated her to such a degree it is impossible to tell. It was perhaps a conformity of indifference to all the rest of the world. Or perhaps the occupation of constantly dictating Letters produced a perseverance of attachment to him, and the continual Show of Sentiment without much of the reality— William Greenleaf came here this morning to assist me in unpacking and putting up my books, and taking a Catalogue of them. We unpacked five of the boxes; put up the books, and took the list of them thus far. I was gratified to find that scarcely any of them had taken damage, although they have been so many years packed up. Some of them were of the packages which came from England in 1817. and some, of those which were returned from the Athenaeum in 1822. Mr and Mrs Foster were here this afternoon: and T. B. Adams jr. Mr Thomas Greenleaf brought me a Message from President Quincy; that he would call upon me next Saturday, concerning the measures to be taken for the establishment of the Academy, or Classical School in this Town. I sent John Thomas in to Boston this afternoon, and he came out with my Son Charles. Mr Degrand came also and spent part of the Evening here— He walked here and back— Miss Anna Thaxter, who has been with us since Saturday also left us to walk home this morning.
7. V. Wednesday.

Mr Humphreys a Surveyor from Weymouth came by appointment this morning with William Spear— I rode with my Son Charles to the foot of Penn’s Hill, and commenced the survey of my farm there. We began with the lands round the two houses at the corner bordering upon Joseph Field, and went round the whole ground lying together, which took us from nine in the morning till half past three in the afternoon— We first found that Mr Samuel Curtis’s fence round the half Acre of ground which I recently conveyed to him has encroached about two links of the Chain upon the measure both in the length and breadth of the lot. I sent for Mr Curtis, and it was measured over more than once in his presence to convince him of the fact; when we came in our progress to the land bordering upon the Nightingale’s, Josiah Nightingale came and observed our course— Deacon Ebenezer Adams met us upon the borders of his territories, and went round with us. Thomas B. Adams jr. joined us soon after we began— William Spear and Baxter carried the Chain, and sticks and measured the ground. I took Dutton out with me at first; but soon dismissed him, finding he had nothing to do. Deacon Adams was plying me all the time he was with us to swop Lands, and to open Ditches. When we came to the
swamp land bordering upon the fields we found, that Harvey Field had built a Wall, for several Rods encroaching upon my lands eight or ten feet and all the buildings connected with the House of the Fields project several feet upon my grounds. Joseph Field, the old man, now eighty years of age came out, as we first were commencing to take the lines, and said something of an agreement of my father with him, that he should extend his shed over the line— When we returned Harvey Field was in his yard, and asked how we had found the line; I told him we thought his wall had encroached; at which he looked concerned, and said that it was parallel to a Wall, which an old Tenant of mine had set on the South side of his lot; and as to the buildings he said his father had told him he had a right to set them a foot farther North than he had done— I told him what his father had said of an agreement with mine, and said I should see how it would turn out upon Mr Humphreys’s plan of our Survey. I spoke to him about his rent, a second Quarter of which is now due; and he after some chaffering said he would transfer his three Canal Shares and one Note for 270 dollars; to pay his full year’s rent, and receive twenty dollars from me— It was past four O’Clock when we got home— There was an invitation to Mr T. Greenleaf’s in the Evening to which Louisa Smith and Elizabeth Foster went; but being much fatigued, and suffering very severely with my Catarrh, I sent an excuse— My brother spent the Evening here. Miss S
8. IV. Thursday—

The day was yesterday so warm that we had no occasion for fires, and I attempted this morning to write without one; but soon found the necessity for it, and made it in my bed-chamber— I still could write little before breakfast, and my writing for the rest of the day is suspended by the Surveys— It was past nine when we called at Deacon Adams’s; and he with Mr Humphreys, William Spear and Baxter were already upon the field. Dutton went with us this day; but T. B. Adams junr. did not— We took this day the Rock Common Wood lots, or as they are described in my fathers deed to me Pastures; one of 23. and one of 20. Acres, now lying together, with four acres; part of a pasture of eight of fresh meadow, for watering Cattle— Deacon Adams says this has always been called Lawyers Common. We were full six hours in going round them— Part of the boundaries are enormous ledges of rock, difficult to scale, and the sides of which are horrid with brambles and briars— The day was very cold and we saw only one Snake, and he of an inoffensive breed. We did not measure the four Acres of fresh meadow or swamp. We found this day, no perceptible encroachment of boundary, but numerous stumps of trees cut down and carried away. About three O’Clock we finished this and then proceeded to the Quincy Meadow described in my deed as of about six Acres. I had always thought it nearly a square, but it is a Trapezium of four unequal sides the Northern, being less than half the length of the Southern side— This plot being only four side, and open ground, I measured it by pacing, and find three of my paces regularly equivalent to a Rod; that is 5 1/2 feet to a Pace— The Chain is more accurate than my pacing, only as it gives the odd links which I cannot do. I shall make a projection of this Lot, upon my measurement of pacing to compare with that of the Surveyor— Deacon Jonathan Bass was harvesting his Indian corn, as we were running the line bordering upon his grounds. He proposed to me to purchase his place. He said there were nine Acres of it, the price he asked for which was 2500 dollars. We reached home to dine, about five—
9— V. Friday.

At nine this morning we met again at Deacon Josiah Adams’s, and proceeded immediately to the Survey of three Woodlots on Pine Hill, conveyed to me by my father’s Deed of 8. August 1803—one conveyed to him by a Committee of the Town of Braintree in 1765, one by Joseph Crosby in and the third by Elkanah Thayer in 1793— The first of fourteen Acres, and the two others of fifteen each more or less. We commenced the admeasurement at a Stone-wall pointed out to us by Deacon Adams as the boundary, and pursued the Wall Southward as long as it continued. It ceased at a deep descent into a swamp, through which we were led by Deacon Adams and the compass, till on the ascent of another Ledge of Rocks the Stone wall recommenced. We followed it until it turned at right Angles, from which Corner, Mr Humphreys took the bearing of the Rail-way Tower, which was in sight— From this Corner, we had no direction excepting as the compass pointed to heaps of Stones from space to space. I had taken much of the morning to look up the Deeds of Conveyance to my father, and had found that of the Committee of the Town, and that of Joseph Crosby; but could not find that of Elkanah Thayer— Deacon Adams knew nothing of the bound, beyond the wall; nor did any other person present— We traversed rocks and swamps through briars and brambles till the descending Sun, warned us of the approach of Night, when we struck a Northern course till we met a Wall by which we traced our way back to the place whence we had started in the morning; and which we reached just after Sunset— After emptying the basket of refreshments which we had left there, we returned to Deacon Adams, and I there agreed with Mr Humphreys that if the weather should be fair next Wednesday he should call again at my house at Eight O’Clock of the Morning. We reached home just as it was dark. The plans can only be completed, by consulting the Report of the Committee of the Town which sold the Lands in 1765. and if it exists the plans then taken— The day was fine, and the weather milder than yesterday— My Catarrhal cold continues with unabated severity; and I was this Evening worn out with fatigue.
10. V. Saturday.

John Thomas went into Boston this morning with my Son Charles in the Chaise. The morning escaped while I was engaged upon my searches for and into the old Deeds of my fathers Estate; which will yet absorb many hours. Mr Quincy came before Noon, and we had conversation upon further proceedings to be had for carrying into effect the establishment of a Classical School in this Town— At the Meeting of the Supervisors of the fund on the 29th. of July last Mr Quincy had been appointed a Committee, to prepare a plan, and Rules and Regulations for the School; he to consult with me— But he had forgotten this Commission, and to obtain a copy of it, and of the other proceedings of that Meeting, we walked to my brother’s House— He was not at home, but we met him as we were proceeding to his Office— Mr Quincy took a copy of the vote— My brother took also the acknowledgment of the Release by Mr Quincy and myself as Executors of my father’s Will, of the Mortgage of his homestead Estate, executed by me, 4 October 1826. to secure the payment of his bequests to Abigail S. and Elizabeth C. Adams— They having since both come of age, and received payment of their bequests by my Notes. After returning to my house, I read to Mr Quincy the copy of my Letter to the Supervisors, of
the 15th. of July last, and he said he would draw up a plan with Rules and Regulations for the School, which he would take from the Academy at Andover— Of those Regulations he promised to send me a Copy. After dinner he spoke of some of the Ancestors of the Quincy family, and I shewed him the extracts I had made from the Braintree Town Records— We walked to the burying yard, where I shewed him the Tomb and Gravestones of Leonard Hoar—of Henry and Margery Flynt, of Joanna, wife of Edmund Quincy, of Judith Rayner—and the Stone; lying on the ground, the Inscription upon it being lost, but which we both took to be the monument of the second Edmund Quincy— Between four and five in the afternoon, he took leave and returned to Cambridge. He told me that he had examined the Records of the Corporation of Harvard University to find accounts of my fathers and my donations of books but could find no trace of them— My cold is still very troublesome, and I made this Evening an unsuccessful attempt to read.
11. V. Sunday—

Heard Mr Kimball, now of Needham; formerly the Preceptor at the Derby Academy in Hingham; when my Sons George and John were there at School. His morning Sermon was from Matthew 5.9. “Blessed are the Peace-makers; for they shall be called the children of God.” upon the benevolent, amiable, pacific character of the Christian Religion— His afternoon text was from Jeremiah 17.9. “The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked: who can know it.” Like almost all the younger preachers of this neighbourhood Mr Kimball writes better than he reads or speaks His voice is feeble and his delivery cold and lifeless— Moral Dissertations upon benevolence, and brotherly love, excellent in themselves are not suited to a tone of high animation. The tediousness of such discourses, is abridged by their brevity. Mr Kimball dined with us I read the 18th Sermon of Dr Freeman’s recent volume, and the charge, with which the Volume concludes— Dr Freeman is Senior Rector of the Stone-chapel in Boston— He was settled in October 1782 and ordained by the members of his own Church 18. Novr 1787. They are Unitarians with the Episcopal forms of worship— He has a Colleague settled with him. F. W. P. Greenwood. He is now very seldom able, to preach, himself: but to protract as long as possible the term of his usefulness he composed and printed this volume of Sermons, and sent copies of it round among his Parishioners— They are published without his name, and are adapted to the festivals of the episcopal Church, from the first Sunday in Advent, till the second Sunday after Easter. The last of the Sermons however is for Thanksgiving day. There is nothing remarkably appropriate, in most of the Sermons, to the several days specially affixed to them. The Christmas Sermon is upon Alms-giving— The Easter Sermon upon the extent of Christ’s Kingdom— The New-Years day Sermon is upon the divisions of the year—astronomical rather than theological— The Sermon upon Marriage is for the second Sunday after the Epiphany the same day as that of Bourdaloue; and upon the same text—doubtless taken from the lesson of the day— These Sermons are all written in a plain and perspicuous Style; full of good sense and sound principle. The learning which they discover is quite superficial, and although they frequently allude to topics of controversy, there is scarcely a single reference to any other writer; excepting to the Scriptures themselves— In the Evening I read the Letters of Pope’s Correspondence with Wycherley, and with W. Walsh— They are monuments of Pope’s juvenile talent and ambition— Wycherly’s Letters are wretched.
12. IV. Monday.

There came a man with a subscription paper from Edmund M. Blunt for six or seven Charts, and to the amount of 80 dollars. He brought a Letter from Blunt, but I declined the subscription— Harvey Field brought me three Certificates of three Shares in the Quincy Canal transferred by him to me, together with a Note from the Treasurer of the Corporation for 70. Dollars, to Adam Curtis, and endorsed by him—which I take in payment of his years rent, and give him a check for 20 dollars— He pressed me for the payment of the Tax assessed upon me, which I declined until I should receive the explanation of the Assessors promised me by Captain Souther, what the property is for which I am taxed. I unpacked two more boxes of my Books, and consumed much of the Morning in examining old Title Deeds— After dinner, I rode with T. B. Adams junr to Mr Asa French’s—the town Clerk of Braintree— My object was to ascertain the bounds of my Pine-hill woodlands, by the Town records; but Mr French was not at home and my work is to do over again— They were Common Lands sold by a Committee of the Town in 1765. of which Committee my father was a member— Mr French’s daughter shewed me the Town Record Books— I found the proceedings of the Town and the appointment and Report of the Committee; but they refer to Plans, of which French’s daughter knew nothing, and which are probably lost or destroyed. The records only led me into enquiries concerning the History of the Braintree Common Lands, which I had not time to pursue— After an hours examination of the Record, Sunset approaching I returned home, and found W. E. Foster, who had come out from Boston for his Sister— We spent the Evening at Mr Whitney’s, and after our return W. and E. Foster left us for Boston. The day was so warm that I had no fire in my chamber, but a clear Northwester brought cold weather again at Night— Going to French’s this afternoon, I stop’d at Josiah Brigham’s and left the Certificates of transferred Canal Shares, for Certificates in my name to be made out. Also at Harvey Field’s, and Henry Hardwick’s, neither of whom was at home.
13. V. Tuesday.

I had not seen Mr William Jarvis since 1792. or 1793, and should now scarcely have recognized him— He resides in Vermont, and married a daughter of Bailey Bartlett of Haverhill— Abigail S. Adams spent the day here with her brother— I received an invitation from J. K. Kane, R. M. Lewis and W Platt, at Philadelphia, to attend at the opening of the Delaware and Chesapeake Canal, next Saturday which I declined— The day was occupied in putting up books of my Library, and in examining old Title Deeds of Lands preparatory to the resumption of the Surveys with Mr Humphreys. My father from an early period of his life, for about forty years was constantly purchasing Lands in Braintree and Quincy. They were of so little value, that he did not pay for them all more than 20,000 dollars— In 1803. after he had ceased purchasing he conveyed to me chiefly at a fair appraisement about one fourth part of those Lands, for 12812 dollars— He gave to my brother Thomas about one fourth part— He gave me in 1819. one fourth part, conditioned for the payment of 1000 dollars a year to him during his life, and the remaining half has been or is to be sold for the benefit of his devisees by Will. I have purchased for about 20000 dollars what has been sold of that half, from which is to be taken a donation of nearly equal value which he made to the Town of
Quincy— The Lands which he conveyed to me in 1803 are those which I am now surveying— I have never known their bounds— Of those which he left, old deeds, and Wills; and scratches of Plans which I could not understand were all I had to discover them— I have this day been examining and making extracts from the Title Deeds of the Lands which I propose to Survey to-morrow—and no one can imagine the time which all such researches consume— The day was gone, and I had got not half through my enquiries, one leading to another. As the Sun was going down, I went to my Nursery and dug with the Spade about half an hour, immediately after which I was taken with a severe touch of Lumbago, which about nine O’Clock I took with me to bed—
14. V. Wednesday.— Surveying

I rose this morning after a painful Night; suffering sharp pains of Lumbago, and with a remnant of Catarrhal Cold and Cough upon me—doubtful of the prudence of going upon fatigue duty; but unwilling to be disappointed in the completion of my undertaking— Mr Humphreys with William Spear and Elijah Baxter, came at 8. O’Clock, and I agreed to meet them at the School-house Lot— Alpheus Spear came with his Quarters Rent, deducting an Account for Butter and Wood— I called round at my brother’s and took up his Son Thomas who accompanied us upon this day’s Survey— We began upon the School-House Lot, which I call so, because a small School-house has been erected upon it, with my brother’s consent, and an acquiescence of mine; we went round it proceeding from the School house corner Southward on the Plymouth road; and thence easterly from Henry Hardwick’s Corner— Hardwick shewed me about an Acre of the Land, which he wishes to purchase. About one third of this Land is covered with a good growth of wood, chiefly Oak and Walnut, with some birch, maple, red cedar, pitch pine and Sumack— The northern Line being open, I measured it by pacing, and found my paces again measuring exactly three to a Rod— On closing the circuit I found Harvey Field, who endorsed the Note of Josiah Brigham, which he transferred to me the day before yesterday. It was by Adam Curtis’s endorsement made payable to him— I called at Samuel Curtis’s and he paid me a Quarter’s Rent, for the house which he occupies— His brother Adam, has already removed into the new house that he has built on the Eastern side of the Road— I asked Samuel when he expected to remove he said he supposed about the first of next September— I ought to take measures for letting the house from this time— I spoke of the excess of measure taken by Curtis in fencing out his half-Acre— He said he had taken nothing beyond French’s measurement and wished to have it measured again by him to which I assented— There is it seems a difference in the length of the Surveyor’s chains— We proceeded to the Penn’s Hill Orchard, Atherton and Virchild lot, commencing at the corner opposite to Henry Hardwick’s House, and taking the direction of the line from East to West, bordering upon Field— We crossed the Atherton and Verchild Pastures, and came in to the Fresh Meadow, and followed the course of the Mill brook, which is the same that leads to the Canal and the town river— After finally crossing this we made our dinner under the shade of Trees on the side of a Hill ascending from it— About five in the afternoon we returned to the point of departure— I ascended the Wall at the same corner, which I had mounted on the 17th. of June 1775. on hearing the Cannonade of that day— We observed that the road had been recently widened by a new wall built eight or ten feet back of
where it had formerly stood— I was told it was done, by a former Tenant of mine, named Green— The last Lot which we measured, was that called the Goose Pasture, on the top of Penn’s Hill, on the East side of the Road the northern bound of which is the line between Quincy and Braintree— It is opposite to Mr Noah Curtis’s House; and he wants to purchase four rods in width from the South side of it— He thinks the whole Lot a barren rock, good for nothing, but said he would give thirty dollars an Acre for it. A Captain Glover joined us there who told me he was the person who in 1826. informed me of the encroachment of Captain James Bracket upon my Cherry-tree Salt-marsh lot— It was the dusk of Evening when I found my Carriage in Harvey Field’s yard at the foot of Penn’s Hill. I left T. B. Adams junr at home, and reached mine just at dark—after six— Weary, stiff and still sharply rhumatic.
15. V. Thursday. Surveying.

Captain Souther called upon me this morning, and gave me a paper explanatory of the tax assessed upon me; with the assistance of which and reference to the Statutes of the Commonwealth, I expect to understand the system of taxation established in the State, and its application to my own person and property— I had hoped to finish this day the Surveys of my Penn’s valley farm Lands, but was disappointed— Mr Humphreys was here between 8 and 9. in the Morning. I proposed to take this day the Saltmarsh. We began with the Penny-ferry Lot at Milton. Sold for 2 3/4 Acres, by Samuel Nightingale to my Grandfather John Adams. 10. April 1738. given by my grandfather’s Will, to his youngest Son Elihu, and by him sold to my father 5. Octr. 1769. and by him to me 8. August 1803. In the Will, and the two last Deeds, the quantity assigned to it is 2 1/2 Acres more or less. A young man by the name of Pope who has mowed it, and whose father has long had charge of it, shewed the bounds, which are a stake at each corner, and a creek, which the lot crosses. It is in the midst of an extensive marsh, overflowed at high tides, and where no other fence could stand. A man named Ezra Penniman owns an adjoining lot and has habitually encroached upon that. We came from it to the cherry-tree stump-lot which was surveyed by Withington in August 1826. and which I now well recollected. It was sold to me for five Acres; but there are encroachers here on both sides—Jesse Fenno and James Bracket. Withington found it very little more than four Acres.— The tide came up and overflowed part of it while we were engaged upon the Survey— When we came next to the Town river lot it was almost wholly overflowed, and we could take only the line bordering upon the upland— Deacon Spear there came to us, and told me a facetious Story of an old man at Germantown, who asked some laborious service of a young one, for which he promised to reward him by telling him something that would be greatly to his advantage: and when the work was done, and the reward claimed said “Jemmy, when you go clamming, take care to go at low water.” The Deacon’s joke was seasonable— We had gone out at low water, but time and tide had out run us, before we could finish the race— We took our scanty dinner on the field, and went to Deacon Adams’s and thence with him on a second search for the Pinehill woodlots; in which search we were not much more successful than before. We traversed however the whole Hill, and came out just at Sunset, on the Southwest side of it, on land of Mr Capen’s— It was dark when we returned to Deacon Adams’s, and too late to return to finish the Survey of the Town-river Marsh lot.
I agreed with Mr Humphreys to meet him there to-morrow morning. Came home again thoroughly weary; and still rhumatic— Mr Colman and Mr Stephen White of Salem had been here while I was afield; and also Mr Dickinson the Stone cutter—Cary’s partner.
16. III:30. Friday. Finished the Surveys.

I retired to bed about 8 last Evening and accordingly rose at half past three this morning— But my writing runs in arrear, and I could not entirely retrieve it— I found this Morning several old Plans of Jedidiah Bass which may assist me in finding boundaries— Among the rest two of the Pine Hill lots N. 5. and 6. and my brother had lent me the day before yesterday the Deed of Elkanah Thayer of 4. Novr. 1793. to my father, containing the description of the Woodlot N. 3— I gave these to Mr Humphreys on the field, at the Town-river lot where I met him this morning; and where we finished my intended Surveys of my Penn’s Valley farm and its appendages, between ten and eleven O’Clock— I agreed with Mr Humphreys to go out with him again Wednesday the 28th. of this Month if fair, to resurvey the Lands belonging to my father’s Estate in the 600 Acres, and which have not yet been ascertained— I spoke to Jonathan Baxter who was ploughing upon his upland bounded on my Salt-marsh lot; which is not fenced— The lot needs ditching for which Baxter recommended to me a Mr Littlefield— I took the measure of Mr Humphreys’s chain which he says is shorter by four inches than that of Asa French— Neither of them is sealed but Mr Humphreys says he will have his Sealed by that of the Official Sealer of weights and measures for the State— As I was returning home I met Peter Turner who told me he had lost an infant this morning in a fit. I spent the remainder of the day in my chamber, having my books unpacked, and putting them up— I have now ascertained with as much exactness as has been in my power the location and bounds of all the Lands in Quincy conveyed to me by my father in his life-time, and the search has made me acquainted with many circumstances relating to their Condition, which I ought to improve to useful purpose; but Patience and Perseverance only can effect what ought to be accomplished— My brother, and his Son Thomas were here in the Evening.
17. III.45. Saturday.

I was occupied all day, in examining my own papers, and the Title Deeds of my father’s Estate; and in unpacking and putting up my books; a work which seems to be lengthening as I go— My Library is l’embarras des Richesses; I have been half a century, as greedy of books as Helluo was of the Salmon’s belly. No such Library exists in the hands of any other individual in the United States; but I have never had the enjoyment of it; nor can I expect to have it now or hereafter for the remnant of my days. My father had the same passion, and finally gave his Library to the Town of Quincy. This ardent love of Literature was indissolubly knit with all the qualities in his character, which raised him to distinction, and signalized the usefulness of his Life— It has had not less influence upon mine— Adolescentiam alunt, Senectutem delectant— It is a costly passion; but pays its own way, with ten fold, and hundred fold increase. But to produce this result it must be associated with rigorous economy, with punctual accountability, and with judicious and untiring
industry. The effect would be much increased by a skilful use of the Library itself. The want of a place in which a Library can be stowed is an inconvenience which nothing but wealth can escape— A large house; and a very large Apartment are indispensable. These I shall probably never possess, and must make up my mind to finish my days without them— I have yet upon my mind also a great burden of private business— My own Affairs—the Settlement of my father’s Estate— The trusts of W. N. Boylston all tax me heavily for Time. I am endeavouring to bring them all into Order; but in the meantime the Memoir of my fathers life must be suspended— My Correspondence abridged, and well it were that I should add, this Diary curtailed— Rufus Davis an old Pensioner, came this morning, with a disastrous tale, having some weeks since broken his arm by an accident; falling into a dock at Boston, and lost at the same time the certificate by which he draws his Pension— I told him to make affidavit of the loss before a magistrate and promised that I would apply for a new certificate for him— At the dusk of Evening I walked to my brother’s and found there a numerous company— Mr Charles Harrod and his two daughters— Mr Marston’s Sister and daughter with two or three young Ladies of the School—two young men by the name of Angier, from Medford, one of whom is a graduate from Cambridge of the present year— Abby S. Adams and Miss Harrod, played on the Piano, and sung; with accompaniment of his voice which is very fine— Edward Miller was there part of the Evening; returned with his wife last Night from Plymouth— The Lieutt. is preparing for his departure.— I walked home before ten.
18. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Richmond of Dorchester, this morning from Psalm 97.2. “Clouds and Darkness are round about him: righteousness and judgment are the habitation of his throne.” A copious theme— In modern English the term Virtue is used to express the idea conveyed in the English Bible by the word Righteousness—defined by Johnson Moral goodness— In the English Old Testament the word virtue is not used— The virtuous man is there the perfect and upright man— In the Hebrew system of Morals the primitive idea of human excellence was rectitude—straightness— Virtue was Right— In the Grecian code of Ethics the primitive idea of perfection was strength— Αρης was the God Mars, and Αρετη was Virtue. In the Roman language Vir was a man, and Virtus—manhood was virtue— Virtue was Power— The Hebrew system came from God— The Grecian system was the work of man. In Mr Richmond’s text Righteousness and Judgment are the habitation of the throne of God. The word Judgment here is equivalent to Justice which is a word of Latin origin from Jus, derived from jubis to command— All the duties of men in the Jewish System are referred to the Will of God— Abstract virtue, the καλον και αγαθον is a conception of the Grecian Sages— Dr Richmond’s text in the afternoon was from Isaiah 5.4— “What could have been done more to my vineyard, that I have not done in it? wherefore when I looked that it should bring forth grapes, brought it forth wild grapes?” This was a discourse of reproof and expostulation which commanded attention, and would have searched the hearts of the hearers if it had been delivered with animation— Dr Richmond dined with us as did my nephew the Lieutenant— Towards Evening I read Swift’s Sermon upon Sleeping in Church, and part of that upon False witness— The former is a tissue of severe Satire from beginning to end— Such that I think there were no Sleepers when it was
delivered— The second is more grave, but appears to have reference only to that species of false testimony which prevails in factious times and is instigated by party Spirit— He describes it as extremely common, and utterly profligate— And to escape it he advises his hearers to have nothing at all to do with that which is commonly called politics or the government of the world: In the nature of which he tells them it is certain they are utterly ignorant— This doctrine would not take at this time— He speaks also with contemptuous indignation— There is much discourse in this Sermon applicable to all heated party times. My brother, with Mr Harrod and Joseph Harrod called here, and we spent the Evening at Mr G. W. Beale’s, hearing Abby S. Adams, Miss Harrod, and Joseph Angier play on the Piano, and sing Hymns, Anthems, and other sacred Music. As we came home Lieutenant T. B. Adams junr called in and took leave: going to morrow Morning on his return to his Post at Sullivan’s Island. S.C.
19. V:30. Monday.

Mr Dickinson came out from Boston with a workman, and they began upon the work of adjusting the tablet bearing the obituary inscription to the side of the Wall in the Stone Temple— I had spoken yesterday to Henry Wood to assist in the performance of the work— He was accordingly early at the house, with Josiah Adams junr. and they worked upon it the whole day. They marked out the space to be covered by the Tablet, from which they took off the plaistering, and cut away the Laths and firring which was of Plank. Wood and Adams were all the afternoon employed in opening holes into the solid Granite Walls, to insert the marble Trusses which are to support the monumental Tablet— Dickinson and his workman returned to Boston, early in the afternoon. I was there several hours of the morning; inspecting the work, and giving directions for the position of the Tablet. Mr T. Greenleaf, my brother, Deacon Spear and some other persons occasionally came in— I went with Henry Wood over to the burying Yard, and examined the Grave-stones there erected by my father, to the Memory of his Ancestors— A corner of the Marble tablet inserted into the Stone of the first Henry Adams is broken off—Mr Wood thinks by the effect of Snow or rainwater dripping in by the edges though soldered with lead, and swelling beneath by the frost till the marble broke— The first of these four Monuments built by my father, was to the Memory of his father and mother— The foundation was of several Stones; with a table covering of one— The lower Stones were joined together by a cement of mortar, but the heaving of the frost has disjoined them and broken away all the Mortar. I desired Mr Wood to replace the Stones, and to secure them as far as may be practicable— The yard itself is too accessible to children from the adjoining School, and even to Cattle. Brass and marble are frail memorials; destined to decay—but the preservation of them, as long as they can be made to endure is a duty of filial piety transmissible from generation to generation— I also told Mr Wood that I desired a certificate signed by several of the persons present, at the removal of the remains of my father and mother, from the tomb in the grave-yard, to the Sepulchre under the Temple. Towards the dusk of the Evening I walked again up to the House, and found Wood and Adams yet at work, cutting
the holes in the Wall for the Trusses— The part of the day that I spent at home was chiefly engaged in unpacking, and putting up books— My eyes threatened with inflammation disconcerted my reading and writing. I have at last got out my Voltaire; and in the Volumes of his General Correspondence found a number of his Letters to Madame La Marquise du Deffant— The first is of 1749. and gives an account of the Death in Childbed of Madame du Chatelet, with whom he was living in a sort of community of goods and of matrimonial rights, with her husband— There is a mixture of burlesque in all Voltaire’s sensibilities. His Letter to Madame du Deffant, to which the first of hers in the collection subjoined to her correspondence with Walpole is the answer, is so grossly and shamelessly indecent, that no virtuous woman would have answered it— But she was living with the President Hénault, much in the Style of Madame du Chatelet with Voltaire.
20. III.30. Tuesday.

I have been so many years accustomed to keep copies of my Letters that I feel a great reluctance at discontinuing the practice— I am now reduced to the alternative of doing it or of employing a Secretary. This morning I wrote a short Letter to my wife and copied it myself; but I have so nearly lost the use of my right hand for writing that I cannot habitually copy. William C. Greenleaf was here this morning, and we made some progress in the Index alphabetical to my proposed catalogue of my books— I begin with a mere alphabetical index of names which when collected I intend to use for reference to the pages of the Catalogue— Mr Greenleaf brought me an original Letter of April 1764. from my father to his Grandfather Cranch; and promised to come again to-morrow Morning. I went to the Meeting House where I found Mr Dickinson, and Mr Wood at work on the Monument. My intention was to have gone again in the afternoon; but Mr Bailey came and took tea here. Mr Loud of Weymouth also called and took back the papers he had left with me last July— He offered me compensation for the trouble I had taken, in this affair which I declined. Mr Bailey mentioned the Manuscript of my Reply to the Boston Confederates; and expressed a strong wish that it might soon be published or at least some part of it— Mr Bailey spoke also of his own situation and prospects: he proposes taking his family with him to Washington this Winter— This is the fourth successive Congress in which he has been a member of the House of Representatives, and he foresees that there is little prospect of his future re-election. He wishes himself back in his office at the Department of State— We had some Conversation upon general politics; of which I am rapidly losing the thread. He promised to send me a copy of the marks and references made by Mr Jefferson in his copy of my father’s Defence of the American Constitutions— I am making an abstract from the Title Deeds and Vouchers of Real Estate, left by my father, which occupies much of my Time— And I make slow progress in putting up my books— Ruth Turner passed the day here, and stays to Night. I read a few Letters of the Correspondence between Voltaire and Madame du Defffant— Her labours are much more laboured and less natural than those she wrote to Walpole; and are therefore less pleasing. Voltaire in the midst of building Chateaux, a Church, a Theatre, settling a Colony, acting Tragedies, writing Histories, Epic Poems, Dramas and Letters, is always complaining that he is sick— Madame du Deffant teizes him to advise her what she shall read— He answers “the Old Testament, especially the book of Ezekiel, Ariosto, and Rabelais,[”] and promises to send her two Books of the Pucelle written in imitation of Ariosto— His criticisms are severe and Summary—particularly upon the English Novelists— He says there is not a good thing in Tom Jones, except the character of a Barber; and that he was tired to death with Clarissa till in the tenth Volume, he met her in a bad house.
21. V. Wednesday.

The Night was cold, and the frost this Morning so sharp that I found myself unable to write in my Diary before breakfast— This throws an arrear upon the whole day— William Greenleaf passed the day and Evening here. I proposed to him to take up his residence with me until I go on to Washington and to assist me in copying papers and making a catalogue of my books, to which he agreed, and after copying two Letters, was engaged all day in making the Alphabetical index of names preparatory for the Catalogue— I went morning and afternoon to the Meeting-House where they were at work on the Monument— The making of the holes in the Wall to receive the Trusses which support the marble Tablet has been a laborious Work— The tablet was in the course of this day put up. I met Mr Daniel Greenleaf there this morning. Mr Wood gave me a certificate signed by himself, Nathan Fisk, Josiah Adams junr. and Benjamin Page, that they removed the remains of my father and mother on the 1st. of April 1828. from the family vault in the burying ground, to the Tomb under the new Stone Temple— Mr Wood informed me that Mr Cary would come out to-morrow— Miss Thaxter dined with us— She had been to the Dedication of the new Stone-Meeting house in Milton, at the Railway; which was done this day. Mr Brooks of Hingham went with her, and dined with the dedicating party there. He called for her here after dinner on his return home. Ruth Turner returned home also this Evening. I made very small progress with my abstract of Title Deeds, and not much more in putting up my books, though I have nearly filled my shelves. In the Evening I read a number of Letters from Voltaire to Madame du Deffand— There is something irresistibly ludicrous in the sportiveness of his Wit, though it is always disgustingly coarse. He appears to have been totally destitute of the Sentiment of delicacy. His indefatigable industry is one of the most remarkable parts of his character, and he tells Madame du Deffand, that his secret for rendering life supportable, is to keep himself incessantly occupied. He says too that with all his other engagements, and with the perpetual stream of visitors especially English and Russians whom he is compelled to entertain, he has to write ten or twelve Letters every day— But he had not lost the use of his right hand.
22. V. Thursday.

Still unable to write before breakfast for the cold. Mr Cary came out from Boston, and carved the names of my father and mother upon the Granite Stones under which they repose in the Tomb beneath the Porch of the Stone Temple. There was nothing on them to designate which was which— The Granite Stone, is so much more intractable than marble, to receive inscriptions that Cary and Wood were at work the whole day in carving the two names. Mr Cary dined with us. I was three times this day at the Meeting-house, and this Evening found the bust of my father put up in its place. The monument is of perfect simplicity; and I hope suited to the character of the persons and the history of their lives— I hope also that it has been erected in a Spirit acceptable to our father who is in Heaven— Not of Pride or Vain-glory; but of filial gratitude, and veneration; and of pure Patriotism— The monument is neat and handsome; but the effect of its appearance in two particulars falls short of my expectations— It projects too much from the Wall, and the Bust which is of white marble, having a white plaistered Wall immediately behind it is seen to great disadvantage— Mr William Smith whom I met there immediately
after the bust was up, spoke of it, and said he hoped I should do something further to give it relief— The visitors to see it are already numerous and their comments as various as the persons— There are few such monuments existing in this Country, and indeed very few Churches of durable structure, in which they could be placed— There are three in the Stone Chapel at Boston— All of ante or anti-revolutionary personages, in whose history no person now here takes any interest; except perhaps the immediate descendants of Charles Ward Apthorp, one of the three— I wrote to my Son Charles, and answered an invitation from the Soul of Soldiery to attend their anniversary celebration next Monday, which I declined— From the Correspondence of Voltaire with Madame du Deffand I passed to Condorcet’s Life of Voltaire—the first thing in which that strikes me is the contrast of character between the biographer and his subject. The greatest charm of Voltaire is in his wit— Condorcet is an emphatic philosopher—always upon stilts— Voltaire to escape persecution for his Epitre à Uranie, gave out that it was written by the Abbe de Chaulieu— Condorcet gravely affirms the right of lying to evade persecution; and yet is ashamed to justify Voltaire— Condorcet’s fate may mitigate criticism upon his Memory— He was a fanatic of Atheism, and sophistical politics— Returned to my bed chamber.
23. V:30. Friday.

A man by the name of Glines came this morning and made application to be engaged next Spring as my Coachman— He had already written to me for that purpose— I told him I kept no Coachman, but might want a man for all family work, who should keep my horses, and occasionally drive them for me when I ride, and if he should be disengaged when I come here next Spring, I should be willing to take him, and will let him know. Mr Appleton, John Gray, and Mr Rice paid me a morning visit, and we had conversation upon the prospect of the march of the Russians to Constantinople— I went to the Meeting house and found that the Monument was finished last Evening; and in the Tomb, I saw that the names of my father and mother were carved upon the Granite Grave Stones, under which they be. I offer to my merciful Creator the tribute of humble Gratitude that his good pleasure has granted me the ability to accomplish this work; and I pray for the blessing of Heaven upon it; that for many ages to come, it may serve as a solemn admonition to all their descendants to their townsmen, and to every one who shall read the Inscription, to devote the service of their God, their Country, and mankind— The key of the Tomb was returned to me this day. After dinner, I walked down to the Mount Wollaston Farm, and over it with the Tenants Alpheus and Spear— They shewed me the eastern and Southern boundary of the farm, and a small piece of Saltmarsh adjoining it which they think is for Sale cheap, and which they wish me to purchase— I saw the trees they had cut down, to cart to my house for fire wood, and a large Oak tree, which Taylor, the man whom I first employed last June when I came here cut down, and then left the trunk there— It was an excellent and valuable tree for Timber, and should not have been cut down for fuel. It was an imposition practiced upon me by Taylor, and with several other incidents proves to me that a man must purchase dear the art of managing his own property when he has been bred to other occupations. The farm is leased to the Spears for five years which will expire on the 1st. of April 1831. They are both anxious, Alpheus especially to have it determined whether the lease is to be renewed or to cease— They have it at a rent already reduced from 1000 to 600 dollars a year; and their object is to reduce it to 500. They are good Tenants; punctual in their payments, and keep the farm in tolerable order.
Deacon Spear was accidentally there, and told me the farm would not pay a rent of more than 500 dollars a year. I promised Alpheus to give him my definitive answer before my departure for Washington— I pursued this Evening the abstract of title deeds, and had time to read only a few pages of Condorcet’s life of Voltaire.
24. IV:45. Saturday.

Mr Humphrey and his Son came this morning, and proposed to me to sell me three tracts of Land in Quincy—Woodland 50 Acres—Pasture 40. and Saltmarsh seven; all in the vicinity of Lands I now own. As non-residents in the Town, the taxes fall heavy upon them— The land is taxed in the Quincy valuation, at 3000 dollars; but times are so hard they are willing to take for them something less. I desired them to furnish me from the title Deeds a description of the boundaries, and a specific Statement of the quantities, and said I would then tell them in five minutes what I would give for the whole— I went to Boston— Dined with my Son Charles, and he and his wife came out with me this Evening to Quincy. Mr John Gorham, son of the late Dr Gorham, and now a student at Cambridge dined with them. I called to visit Mrs Dexter in Federal Street, but found she had removed— I was also at Mr James H. Foster’s, and invited his daughter to come and spend some time with her Aunt, which she promised. I was also at Mr Isaac P. Davis’s, but was informed he was gone to Washington. Both going in to Boston, and returning I stopped at Mr Withington’s In the morning he was gone to Boston— I left at his house the plan taken 12. Decr. 1826. which I had mislaid when we were last out, and since found— In the Evening he told me that he had made the plan; and we agreed if the weather should be fair on Tuesday, to go and stake out the ground.
25. IV:45. Sunday.

This is the anniversary of the marriage of my father and mother, and the first day of public worship at the Meeting House after the erection of the Monument to their Memory— Mr P. Whitney preached, from Luke 16.27. [“]Then he said, I pray thee therefore, father, that thou wouldest send him to my father’s house: 28. For I have five brethren; that he may testify unto them, lest they also come into this place of torment.[”] The Sermon was upon a future retribution, of rewards and of punishments. He noticed the doctrine of Universal Salvation, or of exemption from all punishment hereafter, said it was believed by many—but contradicted by numberless passages of Scripture; and a very pernicious opinion; so I believe it— The effect of the creed upon conduct is not altogether ascertainable: but according to the operation of reason upon my mind the belief of the immortality of the Soul can have no influence upon morals, unless men hold themselves responsible hereafter for the conduct of life here. If all the divine purposes of human existence are accomplished here on earth, there is no consideration physical or moral which warrants the expectation of continued existence after death. The general tenour of the New Testament countenances the belief that the punishments as well as the
rewards of futurity will be eternal; but there are passages of milder aspect, and it is scarcely possible to reconcile the idea of endless punishment with that of divine omnipotence and Mercy. God is almighty— He has made man weak and frail. Transgression is finite— Infinite punishment would be disproportioned to the Offence— Evil cannot be the end of Creation— The afternoon discourse was of the regular Series from 2. Peter 3.16. upon the passages in the New Testament, hard to be understood, and took up the Epistle to the Romans without explaining all its difficulties to my satisfaction— Abigail S. Adams dined with us. G. W. Beale and D. Greenleaf were here in the Evening. I notified him and also Deacon Adams and Captain Josiah Bass to go with us to stake out the ground of the disputed lot, with Mr Withington next Tuesday— I read two Sermons of Swift; one upon the Poor man’s contentment, and one upon the causes of the wretchedness prevailing in Ireland. The sturdiest Tory would not venture to preach such Sermons now.
26. IV. Monday.

Charles and his wife returned this morning to Boston, and Mary Foster came out in the Carriage— Zenas Humphrey brought some of the Title Deeds of the three parcels of Land; which he has for Sale. There are little short of one hundred Acres. 50 of which are woodland 40 pasture turning to Woodland—between 8 and 9. Saltmarsh— They will be sold very cheap, but I cannot afford to purchase them. Daniel and William Spear were here, and the Deacon was discussing my Titles to the lots in the 600 Acres; as usual advising me to give up all that were doubtful or contested. William agreed to go into the Woods with me to-morrow— I unpacked three boxes of Books, and made progress in my abstracts from the Title Deeds of my father’s Estates. After dinner I was going to Peter Turner, to give him notice of our intended expedition to-morrow, when he overtook me, and agreed to go with us. He mentioned to me that Thomas Adams junr. who was going away had a share in the Canal, and had desired him to ask me if I would purchase it, at the same price I had given Harvey Field, for the last Shares I had purchased of him— I told him he might answer that I would give 60 dollars for a share, or 130 dollars for a share and note, which was about the same I had given Mr Field. He said Samuel Savil had also told him that he might offer me his share. I walked this Evening to my brothers, but did not see him. Returned home after dark, and read a few pages of Condorcet’s Life of Voltaire— The cold and solemn Sophistry with which he defends the Pucelle, provokes indignation and contempt— The Pucelle is a work of the grossest and basest immorality that ever was composed— Joan of Arc as a Historical character deserves not ridicule but reverence— She died a martyr for her Country, and if her enthusiasm was fanatical it was from a pure and holy source— She rescued her Country from foreign Invaders— She suffered with heroic fortitude— She was condemned and executed, by the most infamous of trials— Much of the marvellous in her Story is doubtless fabulous, but all the authentic history relating to her, is honorable to her memory. That Shakespear should treat her with injustice admits of some apology— That Voltaire should degrade her is disgraceful to him as a Frenchman. The licentiousness of the Poem is scandalous, and his undying rancour against Christianity was the unworthy motive of his choice of the Subject— The cold blooded philosophical Panderism of Condorcet, is more detestable even, than the cynical profligacy of Voltaire. The Pucelle is fit only to be read in a brothel.
27. III:30. Tuesday.—

The weather was so warm that I slept with an open window on Sunday night— There was last evening a very light sprinkling of rain, and this morning a Crystal sky, Northwest wind, and cold atmosphere— Mr Withington and Daniel Greenleaf came soon after eight O’Clock, and we went for the fourth time into the Woods, to survey and finally adjust the bounds of the lot bordering upon land that was my uncle Peter Boylston Adams’s, upon which lot his Heirs have encroached by mistaken information, received from an old blind man, named Joseph Bass, to whom they gave forty dollars, for pointing out to them this lot of Land as theirs, which belonged in truth to my father There was in all this no design to encroach; and probably no fraudulent intention in Bass—but the consequence has been that Peter Turner sold the wood upon the land; and then sold the Land itself— The descriptions of the Old Deeds are so indefinite that it is impossible to ascertain where the real bounds were; and I have finally been obliged to take an extension of the line at the Western extremity; a swamp of which the land is not worth five dollars, instead of as much land at the eastern entrance of the wood where it is worth perhaps sixty dollars an acre— Thus much for Peace, and to avoid family dissensions, and exposures. We now set up bounds, marking out the exact Quantity of the Land, with the common consent of all parties— Mr Greenleaf, Captain Bass and Deacon Adams appraised the Savil lot at 24. and the large Owen lot at 22 dollars an Acre— Thus that question was settled— There remained the Beale small Owen and small Borland lots to be ascertained, but Mr Withington was unable to proceed any farther— He left us about 2 O’Clock and the three Appraisers went with me, W. Spear and Elijah Baxter over the ground which I propose that Mr Humphreys should survey to-morrow— Peter Turner was also with us. We made the round and got back to Owen’s Field about four in the afternoon, and home about five. Mr Daniel Greenleaf went and returned with me— Peter Turner came in the Evening and brought with him two Deeds, one of William Adams to my uncle Peter, and one of John Hobart to Boylston Adams. I called on Mr G. W. Beale who owns land in the same vicinity; mentioned to him that we should go out to survey to-morrow and proposed to him to go with us which he said he would.
28. IV. Wednesday.

Arcturus rises in the direction from my bed chamber window, of the Sun at the Summer Solstice— I saw him this morning at four O’Clock about ten minutes risen— I recognize him by the nearly perpendicular direction of the two stars of the Great Bear’s tail— My Surveyors came again this Morning, and also the Masons from Boston to Rumfordize my kitchen— Mr Humphrey had a new Chain authentically sealed. His old one was three inches longer— The platform of my book shelf was 22 links and 4 inches by his new chain; or 14 feet 10 inches and 24 hundredths. By the same measure Withington’s Chain is rather more than 1 1/2 inch too long— It is apparent that they stretch by usage. He brought me three of the plans of our first Surveys which he has prepared; but he makes of the Penn’s Valley farm only 91 acres and 3/4 in which there must be a mistake of at least 16 Acres; and probably more than 20. I told him I thought it impossible his plan should be correct, and he took it back to revise it— We went out to resurvey the Lots which we had failed of ascertaining correctly in 1826. We went first to the lot twice surveyed by Mr Withington, once
on the mistaken supposition that it was the 4. Acre Owen lot 30. August 1826. and again on the 25th. of September 1826. when it was taken for the 6. Acre Borland lot, though it did not well correspond in dimensions with that. It was sold at Auction under the first survey, and purchased by me— We resurveyed part of this lot now, but meeting Mr George W. Beale who bordered upon the other lot, and was impatient to go home, we proceeded to that— It is the one surveyed by Jedidiah Bass in 1785. and which by his plan of that time contains more than 20 Acres— Twice surveyed by Withington in 1826 he made it at first over eleven, and the second time less than 14 Acres. Mr Beale went with us to the corner bounds which were ascertained by an indication on Bass’s plan that there were then there four Bass wood trees— Those trees have been cut down, but on the spot where they grew, and where Deacon Adams had seen them standing there are now four young trees of the same wood, and seeming to proceed from one Root, growing— There is a heap of Stones five or six Rods distant from these Trees, by whom put up is unknown—but which now pass for the boundary. Deacon Adams said they were not there when he saw the old Bass-wood trees standing, and he advised me to remove the heap. But I declined removing any thing— We pursued the North western course, till we came to the line between the Towns of Milton and Quincy on the Western border of a deep and except at a dry Season impassable Swamp— We found one of the boundary heaps of Stones, between the towns, and on the top of which is a flat stone with a red cross painted on its nether side— Then changing the course and reascending the hill we returned by a series of old boundary heaps to the four bass-wood trees which we reached just at Sunset—in the mean time having lost Deacon Spear and Peter Turner, who after finding another of the red crossed boundary heaps, made their way home. From our Bass wood trees we had now a walk of near two Miles till we came out at Owen’s field, and thence into the Babel pasture, where my Carriage and the basket of provisions were waiting— We made our dinner there; I took Deacon Adams near his home in my Carriage; and reached home myself, little before seven O’Clock. Elizabeth C. Adams had dined and spent the day here, but soon returned with her brother John Quincy— Alexander H. and Edward Everett had been here this Morning.
29. III:30. Thursday.

Mr Zenas Humphrey came again this morning for my answer respecting the Land which his father and he were inclined to sell me; but which I now declined to purchase— I had found upon enquiry that this Pasture Land was of no value; and they had told me that they had wished to sell the whole at once— He now offered to sell me the Saltmarsh for 60 dollars an Acre, which I declined giving. The price is very low; but I hear there is question about the title; and not wishing to discuss that with him, I broke off upon the price— It is dangerous dealing with these men, and necessary to be versed in their ways, which I am not— Josiah Adams junr. came this morning and I settled with him for the bookshelves he had made for me— I desired him to call again upon me in two or three days—as I must have more made. At nine we proceeded again into the Woods— We met Deacon Adams at Owen’s Field— We commenced from a corner boundary White Oak tree which Peter Turner and Captain Bass, joking upon a blunder of some old proprietor call the tree of three halves—and went round the lot till we came again to the same tree— Josiah Nightingale has a lot of six Acres bordering upon this; and met us there— Some difference occurred between him and Deacon Adams concerning some of the old bounds, and it is yet uncertain whether
our admeasurement will not encroach upon other claims— We went again to the four bass wood trees corner, where Josiah Nightingale shewed the bounds claimed by him, and where the two short lines West and North were again measured— We returned to the white Oak tree about 3 O’Clock and there dined, after which we parted from Mr Humphreys, and I went with Deacon Adams William Spear and Elijah Baxter, over to my large Borland lot to examine where it might be proper to sell off the wood— We passed over the Bunker Hill Ledge Railway which is deserted, and went through my Borland lot. We then returned through Babel pasture, and I parted successively from Deacon Adams, and from William Spear and Elijah Baxter— I had sent Dutton home before— I was walking home, when I met my Carriage, which I had ordered to come for me to the entrance of Babel Pasture at Sunset, and in which I got home about that time. Spent the Evening in my chamber; leisurely writing. I have finished my Surveys for the present, and having been uncommonly favoured by the weather they have been less tedious than I had anticipated. At this Season of the year the leaves have withered, and are falling from the Trees. There is no vegetation, and scarcely a sign of life in the forest. No birds— No beasts— Not even Snakes. What I have most remarked is the difficulty of remembering any track in the wood, and the time that is consumed in measuring very small tracts of Land—a comparatively easy lot of 8 or at most 10 Acres has been almost the whole work of this day— With a little more knowledge of the ground I could with great ease have measured in one day what we have barely got through in three.
30. IV: Friday.

Mr Daniel Greenleaf came this morning to enquire of the dimensions of the Woodlots to be returned and appraised as part of my father’s Estate— I gave him the minute of the four Lots, being 1. The united Owen and Savil lot. 2. The Four Bass wood trees lot; and 3. The White Oak tree lot—from one of which is to be deducted a lot of about ten Acres conveyed to me by his Deed of 23. Septr. 1829— Mr Greenleaf said the appraisement must be made this day as Captain Bass was going upon a Journey to-morrow to be absent till after the next Probate day at Quincy. Mr Marston paid me a morning visit with his son John just returned from a three years cruize in the Pacific Ocean. After dinner Deacon Spear and his brother called with a written advertisement for a sale of standing wood next Friday— The Deacon wishes to begin with a Sale which will produce nothing—of the policy of which I am doubtful; but he will see me again before the sale. I rode with W. C. Greenleaf to Asa French’s town Clerk of Braintree, and enquired of him for the plans of the Commons lots sold by the Town in 1765. but he had them not. He said he had seen one of them within these eighteen Months in the possession of James Brackett who told him it was partly destroyed; but French said that my Pine Hill woodlots were upon that plan. He shewed me the Record books of the Town Clerk and Treasurer. The Treasurer’s book had a statement of all the persons to
whom the lots were sold, and of the sums due from them for the purchase; but the Report of the Committee of Sale, specified none of the lots sold, but by reference to the plans. I told Mr French that Samuel Curtis and myself wished him to survey again the half Acre of Land I sold to Curtis, which he promised to do some day next week; and to call on me, to measure his Chain upon the Platform of my long book shelf. In the Evening I continued my abstract from my father’s Title-deeds, and read a few pages of Condorcet’s life of Voltaire— I unexpectedly find it dull.
31. V. Saturday.

I had the day before yesterday received a Letter from Nathaniel Curtis, enclosing one from Petty Vaughan, in answer to that of the Executors of W. N. Boylston’s Letter of the 24th of August last. Mr Curtis mentioned that there would be an opportunity to write by the Amethyst to sail for Liverpool to-morrow. Taking up Curtis’s Letter this morning, which in the weariness after three days of surveying I had not marked with sufficient attention, I saw that the business must be despatched this day, or that this opportunity for writing would be lost. I wrote immediately to Petty Vaughan, and with a duplicate of my Letter of 29. September went with John Thomas in the Chaise into Boston, against a violent Northwest Storm— I applied at the probate Office for a duplicate authenticated copy of the Letter of Administration upon the non-administered Estate of Thomas Boylston, which was furnished me, and which I took to the lodgings of Mr Bangs the Secretary of the Commonwealth, for the authenticating certificate of the Governor— I sent for it after dinner, and enclosed it with my Letter to Petty Vaughan, and left it with Charles to be sent to the Post-Office this Evening. I enquired also at the Registry of Deeds, for the Records of the Original Deeds of the Braintree Common-lands; from the Claimants in Boston, with whom they compromised in 1700 and 1709— Both of them were found; and I requested copies of them to be made out which I was promised for Monday or Tuesday. J. B. Davis called twice at the Office of my Son Charles, and returned me the Manuscript of my reply to the confederate appeal, with an earnest wish that it might be immediately published—but I propose to wait yet some time— I had seen at Charles Brooks’s shop some Patent Steel two foot Rules and went there to purchase one; but found them on comparing them with some imported English two foot rules, nearly an eighth of an inch too short. Brooks took one of them to the City Surveyor Beale, who told him that there was no State Standard; nor any authentic long measure in the State. I posted up at the old and the new Court-house notifications of my appointment as Administrator de bonis non, with the Will annexed of Thomas Boylston—dined with my Son Charles, and after much hesitation, the Storm still continuing returned this Evening to Quincy— I reached home just after dark: disqualified for Evening toil, but read some pages of Condorcet’s Life of Voltaire.

Day— The distribution of Time has been necessarily diversified from that of the last Month. My reading before breakfast and writing of my Diary has continued, but I have given the Month to surveys; to arrangements in my house and to the transportation of my Library hither, unpacking and putting up my books; an operation not yet completed— Before the expiration of another Month I must remove to Washington— The arrangement of my father’s papers is entirely suspended and the Memoir of his Life barely commenced. The erection of the monument to the memory of my Parents has this month been completed— The more durable monument is yet but in prayer.
